comment.author: 35179849@N08
comment._content: The seems a bit strange,  because Punchbowl road doesn't connect to the Hume highway,  at either end.

comment.author: 55198937@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/mich2009] This is actually Coronation Parade, Enfield. It may have been called Punchbowl Rd at some time, however is different to the present Punchbowl Road, which connects with Coronation Parade, about 1km further south.

comment.author: 35179849@N08
comment._content: Absolutely right,  the building with the little dome is still there.  Or at least,  it was when the Google Streetview car drove past.

comment.author: 37426109@N07
comment._content: Coronation Parade was originally called The Boulevard and Punchbowl Road respectively, the two ran parallel to each other, separated by the tram-line, tracks are visible in this photo. The tram-line ran from Enfield through to Burwood Road, Burwood, and through suburbs of Concord, Cabarita and Mortlake. Coronation parade was was so named for the coronation of King George VI in 1937, and with the closure of the tram-line the adjoining Coronation reserve as seen on the left of the tracks was widened when the line was closed. More interesting reading about this scene can be found here

comment.author: 37426109@N07
comment._content: The building with the little dome is the Enfield Council Chambers, when it was a suburb with it's own council. Once abolished, half of Enfield was placed in the southern east ward of Strathfield Council, and the other half was placed in the administration of Burwood councils south west ward. To this day in 2013, this has been the case. The old Enfield Chambers lie on the border and are in the jurisdiction of Strathfield council who have it on their heritage register.
